prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for wanting their girlfriend to start paying some bills after a single incident where she had to pay for takeout.

First, the setup: They live together. The author pays all the rent and bills. The girlfriend works part-time. The incident was that the author forgot their wallet, asked her to pay for $40 takeout, and she had a negative reaction. Now the author is considering making her pay some bills as a result.

So, the main question is whether this is fair. Let's consider both sides.

On the author's side: They've been covering all expenses, which is a lot. The incident was a small amount, but the girlfriend's reaction was unpleasant. The author feels it's about principle—maybe they want her to start contributing to avoid future resentment or to share the financial load. The author's frustration is understandable; if someone is living with you and not contributing, even a little, it can feel unfair over time.

On the girlfriend's side: She only works part-time, so her income is limited. She might already be contributing in other ways, like with chores or emotional support. The takeout was an unexpected expense, and she might have felt it was unfair to ask her for that when the author usually covers everything. Her reaction could stem from feeling taken advantage of, even if it's just one instance. Also, expecting her to pay for bills when her income is low might not be feasible.

The key points here are contribution, fairness, and communication. The author might be right in wanting her to contribute a little, but making her pay bills over a single incident seems harsh, especially if she can't afford it. It's possible that there's a communication breakdown—they might not have discussed financial expectations beforehand. The author's frustration is valid, but the approach of making her pay bills immediately after one incident could be seen as punitive rather than a fair adjustment. It's important to consider her financial situation and discuss this openly rather than reacting based on one event. So, maybe the author is in the wrong for not addressing this more calmly and considering her circumstances. Alternatively, if the author has been covering everything and feels it's unfair, they might not be in the wrong, but they need to approach it more thoughtfully. Hmm, this is tricky.
